subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Any one can help me?Question
author: Frank Sumption
full_text:
I'd have the radio in front of me on the bench. I never have schmatics for
the tuners, I use my instruments.

> > > > > to

> are
> > > not
> > > > > > getting many whole words and phrases, that way it's not so
> confusing
> > > to
> > > > > > listen to. the ghsot voices should kinda pop out of the raw
> audio.

> > > > > > > frecuencie min is .....

> 40yahoogroups.com><EVP-ITC%
> > > 40yahoogroups.com> <EVP-ITC%
> > >
> > > > > 40yahoogroups.com>, Frank Sumption
> > > > > > > <purplealiengirl@> wrote:
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > I make the triangle sweep adjustable so I can cover the
> entire AM
> > > or
> > > > > FM
> > > > > > > > band. Some tuners have different sweep requirements for each
> > > band, so
> > > > > > > > sometimes have to add a pot to adjust the max level for one
> of
> > > the
> > > > > bands.
> > > > > > > > AM=530 to 1710 Khz and FM 88.5 to 108mhz, but you don't have
> to
> > > cover
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > > entire band, all that is required is enough to provide the
> raw
> > > audio
> > > > > bits
> > > > > > > > the entities use to make their voices.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > A Danish researcher back in the 80s was just "wobbling"
> between a
> > > > > couple
> > > > > > > > stations to make contact. His name was Stein and there's more
> > > info on
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > > German VTF site. Stein also has his sweep circuit there.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > The best sounding systems seem to be the way Steve Hultay
> makes
> > > his,
> > > > > by
> > > > > > > > adding sweep to a complete radio. see keyportparanormal.com.
> I
> > > take
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > > tuners out of the radio, and supply my own amplifier and
> sweep.
> > > At
> > > > > > > present
> > > > > > > > I'm making a box using a Timex clock radio tuner, the
> triangle
> > > sweep,
> > > > > and
> > > > > > > > computer sound amplifier and speaker system for the bass
> > > response. I
> > > > > just
> > > > > > > > started this project yesterday. I use Timex model T309T
> > > AM/FM/nature
> > > > > > > sounds
> > > > > > > > clock radios when I can find them in thrift stores cheap. I
> found
> > > a
> > > > > Timex
> > > > > > > > model T313T this morning, and hoping it has the seperate
> tuner
> > > board
> > > > > > > inside,
> > > > > > > > as the 300 series has so far.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > I used to use car stereo tuner modules, but those tend to be
> too
> > > > > noisy.
> > > > > > > Box
> > > > > > > > 13, that Hultay just got back is based on a car tuner. He did
> a
> > > > > YouTube
> > > > > > > > video of it.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > I'm still pretty much an amateur at this, there are so many
> > > > > variables.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > Frank-S
> > > > > > > >

> > > > > > > > > > Aluminum seems to work the best. I got a voice that
> sounded
> > > like
> > > > > > > Raudive
> > > > > > > > > > saying copper. I have used plastic and wood. Different
> > > materials
> > > > > seem
> > > > > > > to
> > > > > > > > > > allow different levels, but it's hard to tell for sure
> > > who/what
> > > > > is
> > > > > > > > > talking.
> > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > Folding the tube seems to make it act like a larger tube.
> > > With
> > > > > just a
> > > > > > > > > long
> > > > > > > > > > straight tube the sound tends to be tinny. I made a
> chamber
> > > 12
> > > > > inches
> > > > > > > > > square
> > > > > > > > > > and 4 feet long from MDF board lined with aluminum foil
> years
> > > > > ago,
> > > > > > > the
> > > > > > > > > > voices were almost demonic sounding, so I took it apart.
> > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > The only difference with the hacked radio is the sweep.
> With
> > > the
> > > > > hack
> > > > > > > > > radio
> > > > > > > > > > the sweep steps so the radio is tuned in 10khz
> increments.
> > > With
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > box
> > > > > > > > > it's
> > > > > > > > > > a continuous sweep, linear uses a triangle wave.
